I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is committed to managing for development results 
(MfDR) with a focus on (i) building the institutional capacity and development of demand for 
MfDR  through  leadership  and  participatory  performance-based  planning  and  budgeting, 
(ii) strengthening data and information systems for monitoring and evaluation of results, and 
(iii) developing  processes  for  mutual  accountability  and  feedback.  The  Pacific  developing 
member countries (PDMCs) recommitted to MfDR objectives during the 3rd International Round 
Table in Hanoi on 4 February 2007. Strengthening portfolio performance, which is historically 
weak in the region, is critical to achieving MfDR in the PDMCs. By incorporating an MfDR 
approach in portfolio management, ADB targets improved planning, monitoring, and evaluation 
of operations. Results-based portfolio management, in turn, calls for greater participation of 
project  managers  in  results-oriented  strategy  and  program  planning,  project  design,  and 
preparation of design and monitoring frameworks.  
 
2.  Achieving  MfDR  in  the  Pacific  requires  capacity  development  of  PDMC  project 
managers in setting the results agenda in the national development strategies and ADB country 
partnership strategies (CPSs). It also entails strengthened capacity to design results-based 
projects  and  technical  assistance  (TA),  and  monitor  the  results  during  implementation. 
Therefore,  capacity  building  proposed  under  this  regional  TA1 (RETA)  project  is  aimed  at 
developing  project  management  professionals  to  champion  MfDR  by  strengthening  their 
capacity to foster commitment to results orientation in strategic planning, project design, and 
implementation work. The TA will provide tools and skills to empower Pacific project managers 
to steer project implementation toward achieving tangible development outcomes set forth in the 
national plans and CPSs. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  ADB’s  experience  in  the  Pacific  (Table  1)  reflects  slower  than  average  project 
implementation despite the presence of conducive factors to smooth implementation, such as 
high education levels.

4.  Project portfolio reviews have revealed operational reasons for the less-than-satisfactory 
performance, including lack of (i) clear sector strategies; (ii) baseline data for the indicators at 
outcome levels across all sectors; and (iii) understanding and accountability for the country, 
sector, and project level outcome targets and input-output relationships. These reasons not only 
challenge the ability to assess project and portfolio contributions to development impacts, they 
also cause operational problems of slow disbursement, delayed implementation, noncompliance 
with  covenants,  and  inadequate  project  input  delivery—limiting  the  achievement  of  project 
outcomes.

5.  Portfolio reviews have also concluded that limited achievement of development results in 
the region have stemmed from (i) inadequate involvement of government officials in identifying 
results objectives to which projects contribute; (ii) limited capacity of project implementation staff  
to participate in project design, resulting in weak ownership and understanding of the policy 
action  plans  supported  by  the  project  work  at  the  outset  and  during  implementation; 
(iii) inadequate use and knowledge of transparent procurement and disbursement processes, 
leading  to  delays  in  project  implementation;  (iv)  limited  project  management  skills;  and 
(v) limited accountability by the implementation team for the results targeted by the project. 
 
6.  Past project implementation training, while useful, has focused on input and activity 
levels, primarily procurement and disbursement procedures. The Regional TA2 piloted project 
cycle-based project management training, and yielded immediate responses of satisfaction and 
interest among the region’s project management units (PMUs). Accordingly, the TA will adopt a 
more comprehensive capacity development approach to generate understanding of the strategic 
development objectives, project level impact contributions, linkages between the project inputs 
and outputs, iterative and interactive implications of policy environments, and sequencing of 
project activities as building blocks to attain the intended results.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  As part of ADB-wide effort to mainstream MfDR approaches,3 the TA will assist the 
selected PDMCs in  achieving sector objectives that contribute to national development goals, 
measured by attainment of the outcomes for the majority of ADB-funded projects. The TA 
outcome is MfDR-based project management for ADB projects.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
8.  The TA will assess project management capacity building needs by identifying binding 
constraints  to  adoption  of  the  MfDR  approach  throughout  the  project  cycle.  The  TA  will 
commence with surveys in PDMCs,4 selected on the basis of their ongoing and proposed project 
portfolios, that will identify capacity constraints in the critical MfDR areas. Subsequently, the TA 
will design and deliver modular programs for skills development of all PDMCs with Project 
Management  Units  (PAUs)  to  strengthen  ownership  and  delivery  of  results-based  project 
implementation  to  pursue  MfDR.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  through  the  following  four 
components: 
 
(i)  PDMCs’  capacity  for  adopting  MfDR.  The  TA  will  survey  the  results 
management  issues  across  PDMCs,  incorporating  lessons  from  experience 
gained by ADB in implementation of MfDR systems, to design capacity building 
curricula capable of alleviating the binding constraints that impede adoption of 
MfDR  in  PDMCs.  The  TA  will  deliver  reinforcing  capacity  building  for  target 
groups, including the management level, to develop accountability for MfDR-

and outcome levels. 
 
(ii)  Specific country capacity assessments. Country-specific assessments will be 
conducted for the Fiji Islands, Papua New Guinea (PNG), Samoa, Timor-Leste, 
and Tonga in six areas of results-based (a) planning; (b) financial management 
and procurement; (c) human resources and civil service management of projects; 
(d) statistics;  (e)  auditing;  and  (f)  legal  framework  and  execution  and 
procurement procedure5 reviews in a subset of PDMCs6 (including Fiji Islands, 
Kiribati, and PNG). 
 
(iii)  Capacity for results-focused policies. Based on the above assessments, the 
TA will design a modular curriculum for capacity development to upgrade the 
PMUs’ skills, covering planning for national development strategy objectives, 
policy  results,  interfaces  with  project  contributions,  and  risks  and  mitigation 
arrangements.  It  will  develop  the  PMUs’  capacity  to  target  policy  outcomes 
through project design and inputs, and manage associated advisory TA (ADTA) 
projects. The training will develop a clear understanding of the policy objectives 
and greater awareness of the role of the PMU. It will enable project managers to 
contribute more effectively to the preparation of national plans and project targets, 
promoting a design of realistic and pragmatic development objectives that link 
with sector and project outcomes. 
 
(iv)  Results-focused  project  management.  The  TA  will  build  on  past  project 
implementation training for all PDMCs, adopting a project cycle process as the 
basis  for  the  training.  While  concrete  project  management  areas  (e.g., 
procurement,  consultant  engagement,  and  disbursement  processes)  remain 
important, the project cycle-based sequencing offers procedural problem-solving 
tools and skills for managers to strive toward results in each stage of the project 
cycle.  
 
9.  The  TA  will  build  capacity  by  reinforcing  modules  and  a  dynamic  methodology  on 
efficient use of project management tools, ranging from mentoring arrangements to formal 
training events to develop a class of professional project managers in the Pacific. Capacity 
building will be delivered over a 3-year implementation period, involving all PDMCs7 in (i) annual 
hub-based  results-based  project  management  workshops;  (ii)  a  workshop  for  finance 
secretaries and ministers involved in project design and preparation; and (iii) establishment of 
an interactive help-desk and/or interactive website for project managers to dialogue on project 
issues and access tested solutions to problems. 
 
10.  Topics covered under the capacity development will include (i) results-based national 
planning and development partner strategy planning and programming, emphasizing portfolio 
evaluation; (ii) results-based project design, with a focus on binding constraints, lessons learned, 
and project cycle interfaces with national results objectives; (iii) results-based country portfolio

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $900,000 equivalent, of which $800,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The 
TA will finance four PDMC MfDR capacity assessments; three procurement assessments; four 
regional hub-based workshops; and proposals for user-friendly project management systems; 
interactive helpdesk and/or website with 22 person-months of international and 18 person-
months of local consulting services. The PDMC governments will contribute $100,000 in kind 
through the provision of office accommodation and transport. The cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  The TA will be implemented over 3 years from April 2008 to March 2011. ADB will be the 
Executing Agency of the TA. All PDMCs have been invited to participate in the assistance. 
Activities under the TA will only commence in a particular country when ADB has received the 
no-objection to the inclusion of the PDMC from the concerned government. The South Pacific 
Subregional Office (SPSO) will implement the TA in close cooperation with Central Operations 
Services  Office  (COSO),  Controller’s  Department  (CTL),  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development  Department  (RSDD),  and  sector  agencies  in  the  participating  PDMCs.  The 
ministries of finance and their planning sections are the focal counterparts in the implementation 
of the TA. 
 
13.  International consultants, assisted by national consultants, will be engaged as follows: 
(i) an international MfDR specialist assisted by a national consultant for a total of 22 person-
months (including about 2 person-months per country for five selected countries) to conduct 
MfDR  capacity  and  readiness  assessment  of  PDMCs;  (ii)  an  international  procurement 
specialist assisted by a national consultant for a total of 12 person-months (2 person-months 
per  country  for  three  selected  countries)  for  analysis  of  procurement  systems;  (iii)  an 
international  facilitator  for  participatory  planning  and  management  training  for  a  total  of  3 
person-months (on an intermittent basis) during TA implementation; and (iv) an international 
procedural  expert  for  3 person-months,  with  extensive  experience  in  ADB  project  approval 
processes. The international experts will be responsible for developing terms of reference and 
work plans for the national consultants, in close consultation with SPSO and government focal 
points. 
 
14.  The  TA  will  conduct  four  hub-based  workshops—three  for  project  implementation, 
procurement, and disbursement—involving PMU personnel from ADB-funded projects in all 
PDMCs.  The  fourth  workshop  will cater  for senior  government  officials  heavily  involved  in 
project design, including finance secretaries and ministers, as feasible. SPSO will facilitate 
these workshops. The terms of reference for the consulting services are in Appendix 3.

5
15.  The  consultants  will  be  recruited  on  an  individual  basis  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) using the quality 
and cost-based selection method. All equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) and returned to ADB upon 
completion of the TA. 
 
16.  The reports of the consultant team will be in English, in publishable quality, and in three 
copies. The consultant will also provide three CD-rom versions to ADB. Reports will include the 
following: (i) an inception report that provides a clear work plan and methodology under each of 
the  four  TA  components;  (ii)  a  midterm  report,  to  be  submitted  after  the  surveys  and 
assessments have been concluded, which includes curricula and organizational details for the 
capacity building, an outline of training materials, and recommendations for the interactive help 
desk and website; (iii) a draft final report; and (iv) a final report, covering all activities under the 
terms of reference, giving in full the training materials, including on CDs. The inception, midterm, 
and draft final reports will be reviewed in tripartite meetings between the consultant, ADB, and 
selected government representatives.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
Results-Based  Project  Management  for  Pacific  Developing  Member  Countries,  and  hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Pacific  Developing  Member  Country  (PDMC)  Capacity  for  Managing  for 
Development Results (MfDR) 
 
1.  MfDR Specialist/Team Leader (international, 10 person-months) 
 
1.  The MfDR specialist/team leader will do the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare detailed work plans for the national consultant for Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) approval, and will support selection processes for the engagement 
of qualified national consultant. 
(ii)  Have  experience  in  conducting  MfDR  assessments  with  developing  member 
countries, using the technical and capacity assessment tools.1 Country-specific 
assessments will be conducted for the Fiji Islands, Papua New Guinea (PNG), 
Samoa, Timor-Leste, and Tonga in six areas under MfDR: (a) results-based 
planning, (b) results-based financial management and procurement, (c) results-
based  project  human  resources  and  civil  service  management,  (d) results-
focused statistics, (e) results auditing, and (f) results-oriented legal framework 
and execution. 
(iii)  To develop, in agreement with the counterpart agency, recommendations and an 
action plan with timelines to move the selected PDMCs toward MfDR. 
(iv)  For MfDR sustainability, he/she will mentor and provide hands-on training for the 
national consultant and at least one government official in each selected PDMC. 
(v)  To design; prepare materials for; and, deliver in-country or hub-based training in 
MfDR  for  selected  countries.  The  competency  assessment  will  include  the 
participants preparing a brief report on the course, describing how MfDR will be 
useful in their workplace and a presentation to at least three people in their 
agency or government. 
(vi)  To  design,  in  conjunction  with  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  team,  effective 
monitoring  mechanisms  and  arrangements  for  competency  testing  and  local 
training  to  be  delivered  by  the  participants,  and  feedback  loops  to  ensure 
adoption of lessons by the TA from the effectiveness evaluation analysis into the 
TA implementation. 
(vii)  To consolidate and assume responsibility for all reports and materials produced 
and required under the TA at publishable quality. 
 
2.  MfDR Assessment Assistant (national, 12 person-months) 
 
2.  The MfDR assessment assistant will accomplish the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Organize in-country assessments, including seminars and workshops, as required. 
(ii)  Review,  analyze  and  summarize  all  relevant  documentation  on  the  MfDR 
assessments  in  the  selected  countries;  evaluate  and  discuss  with  country 
authorities their experience and impediments for mainstreaming MfDR approaches, 
covering project impact, outcome, output, and input management and monitoring

functionality  of  the  feedback  loops,  and  decision-making  processes  for 
incorporating lessons in future programs and activities. 
(iii)  Support and facilitate mentoring and training under the TA, including design and 
preparation of training materials for the training sessions and assist with design of 
appropriate trainer training.  
(iv)  Assist in design of the competency assessments, ensuring their suitability and 
appropriateness in the context of the country, and facilitate administration of the 
competency  assessments;  and  assist  with  monitoring  the  training  by  the 
participants in their respective countries.   
(v)  Assist  with  preparation  of  the  reports,  management  and  facilitation  of  the  TA 
activities and inputs of the consultant team, as required by the Team Leader. 
 
B.  Support for Use of Country Procurement System 
 
1.  Public Procurement Specialist (international, 6 person-months) 
 
3.  The public procurement specialist will do the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare detailed terms of reference and work plans for the national consultant for 
ADB approval, and support selection processes for the engagement of qualified 
national consultant. 
(ii)  Have extensive experience in public procurement systems and procedures and 
their legal frameworks. 
(iii)  To  conduct  a  diagnostics  review  of  country  procurement  systems  and 
procedures2 for Fiji Islands, Kiribati, and PNG in the selected PDMCs, using 
indicators3 in  close  consultation  with  the  Central  Operations  Services  Office 
(COSO). 
(iv)  To develop specific recommendations for policy and capacity improvement and 
an action plan for selected PDMCs and executing agencies (EAs) on the use of 
country procurement systems.  
(v)  To develop a training manual, at publishable quality and acceptable to ADB, and 
provide  training  in  each  selected  PDMC  and  their  EAs  to  apply  country 
procurement systems to ADB-financed projects in consultation with COSO. The 
training will target government officials in the selected countries involved in the 
procurement  processes.  To  develop  competency  tests  to  be  taken  by  the 
participants,  analyze  the  results,  and  adjust  subsequent  training  programs 
accordingly.  To  also  make  arrangements  for  the  participants  to  train  local 
procurement officials in the areas discussed in the training manual and evaluate 
the effectiveness of this training.  
 
2.  Legal Adviser (national, 6 person-months per country) 
 
4.  The legal adviser will undertake the following tasks:

procurement  processes  in  the  selected  PDMCs,  determining  areas  for 
improvement of the procurement processes. 
(ii)  Draft  proposal  for  filling  legislative  gaps  with  the  objective  to  upgrade  the

(iii)  Support and assist the procurement specialist, as required, in facilitating training,

C.  Capacity Building in Results-Based Project Implementation and Administration 
 
5.  This area will be led by the South Pacific Subregional Office (SPSO), in conjunction with 
COSO and ADB’s Controller’s Department, from ADB headquarters in Manila, Philippines. 
 
1.  Facilitator (3 person-months) 
 
6.  The facilitator will do the following: 
   
(i)  Have extensive experience in conducting workshops and be familiar with ADB’s 
project performance management system. He/she will build on past workshops 
and implement lessons learned into modules and other aspects of the training.  
(ii)  To review past and ongoing project implementation training modules, design and 
prepare a hub- and modular-based program over the course of the TA to deliver 
effective MfDR-based project management course outline and content for the 
PDMCs  with  ADB  approval.  The  training  program  will  be  prepared  in  close 
consultation with relevant ADB offices, through SPSO, and in cooperation and 
collaboration with the TA team. The workshops will be for a period of 10 days 
and will cater for 30 participants, including all PDMCs. To develop competency 
tests to be taken by participants, analyze the results, adjust subsequent training 
programs accordingly, and report on the analysis in the progress reports. To also 
make arrangements for the participants to train local procurement officials in the 
areas discussed in the training manual, and evaluate the effectiveness of this 
training in the progress report. 
(iii)  To liaise with the procurement specialist engaged under the TA, to ensure that 
any relevant findings from the procurement systems review are included in the 
procurement module of the training. 
 
D.  Results-Focused Project Design and Interventions 
 
1.  International Consultant (3 person-months) 
 
7.  The international consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Have extensive experience in ADB’s project proposal processes. 
(ii)  To develop training materials to conduct a 3-day workshop for senior government 
officials involved in project design. Areas to be covered include results-focused 
project design, rationale behind covenants, intended policy outcomes, minimizing 
project timing delays, capacity building initiatives, and the project performance 
management system. To develop competency tests to be taken by participants,

analyze the results, adjust the subsequent training programs accordingly, and 
report on the analysis in the progress reports. To also make arrangements for 
participants to train local procurement officials in the areas discussed in the 
training manual, and evaluate the effectiveness of this training in the progress 
report. 
(iii)  CD-roms with all the training modules are to be distributed to all participants at 
the end of the workshop. Five copies will be submitted to ADB. The output of this 
training is expected to be greater involvement of local project management and 
senior officials to achieve better project designs and results-focused projects, 
based  on  more  productive  and  constructive  consultation  during  project 
processing. 
(iv)  In conjunction with the TA team, he/she under supervision by SPSO and in close 
consultation  with  relevant  ADB  departments,  develop  recommendations  to 
improve Loan Finance Information System training and project administration 
memorandum format. To help to design a survey to assess the use of the current 
tools.  The  survey  results  will  help  develop  improved  value-added  versions. 
He/she will recommend format and arrangements for establishing interactive help 
desk and web-based support and training tools, including e-learning tools for self-
help, in close consultation with COSO and the Office of Information Systems and 
Technology that have commenced work in this area. 
 
E.  Reports 
 
8.  The  lead  consultant  will  oversee  and  be  responsible  for  the  quality  of  all  reports, 
documentation and submissions produced under the TA.  
 
(i)  Inception report. This brief report will be submitted by the team leader within 
2 weeks  of  mobilizing  in  the  selected  PDMC.  It  will  outline  the  consultants’ 
approach and methodology, and provide a work plan for implementation of the 
TA component, as agreed with government stakeholders and ADB. The report 
will  provide  a  bar  chart  of  all  activities  under  the  TA,  and  recommend 
implementation arrangements. 
(ii)  Progress reports. These brief reports will (a) inform the governments and ADB 
of achievements under each item of the terms of reference; (b) identify, if any, 
emerging difficulties in implementation; and (c) outline proposed solutions. The 
reports will provide, in clear presentations, the status of implementing the terms 
of reference; summaries of the substantive and progressive planning for the 
reform  program;  constraints  and  opportunities;  challenges  to  the  program 
preparation;  and  include  a  TA  component  performance  status;  plans  for 
achieving the objectives; personnel schedule with accomplishments under each 
item  of  the  terms  of  reference.  These  reports  will  adopt  a  uniform  format 
facilitating monitoring, and will update the bar chart on all activities under the TA. 
They will cover (in the appendixes) analysis of the test results and lessons 
learned for the various training programs delivered, and evaluation of the training 
delivered by the participants in the PDMCs.  
(iii)  Midterm  report.  A  midterm  report  will  be  submitted  after  the  surveys  and

organizational details, and recommendations for an interactive help desk and 
website.  This  will  also  include  appendixes  for  MfDR  and  procurement 
assessments.

(iv)  Draft final report. This report will (a) be submitted on completion of the TA 
component  in  each  country;  (b)  summarize  the  TA  activities  and 
recommendations; and (c) provide recommendations on each item under the
